bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jessie Daniel Ames, February 4, 1942

div1.p: Hench requests to borrow Roger Ames' papers and photographs for the purposes of his research.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jessie Daniel Ames, February 4, 1942
div1.opener:
Y F.
February 4, 1942
Mrs. Roger Post Ames
General Field Secretary
Commission on Interracial Cooperation
710 Standard Building
Atlanta, Georgia
My dear Mrs. Ames:
div1.p:
I was so glad to receive from Mr. George Kellogg your address.
For some time I have known of the work of your husband and indeed was one of
those who proposed that your husband be included in the painting “Conquerors
of Yellow Fever.” Permit me to send you a couple of reprints which will evi-
dence my interest in the story of yellow fever. I have uncovered so much un-
published material concerning the conquest of yellow fever that the Mayo Clinic
has authorized me to proceed with the publication of a book thereon and I am
collecting further data now.

Two weeks ago in Washington I visited Mrs. Walter Reed and her
family, certain relatives of Dr. Lazear, General Kean, General Ireland and others.
Mrs. Blossom Reed let me copy all her father's letters that were available. La-
zear's family uncovered many letters of Dr. Lazear, written from Cuba to his
mother, and gave these to me. Here and there I have found old photographs of
Camp Lazear, Camp Columbia, etc. Returning from Chicago I visited Gust. Lambert
for three or four hours. He especially told me of the splendid work of your
husband and showed me a photograph of him. I am sorry indeed that none of us
knew your address or the whereabouts of the photograph. Otherwise, I am sure
Mr. Cornwell would have made a better likeness of him in the painting.

I learned from Mr. Lambert more about your husband's work than
I had learned elsewhere and I am taking the liberty of writing you asking for
further help. As I understand it, you have some letters between him and Walter
Reed and others, one letter concerning your husband's work; also certain newspaper
clippings and articles. Do you have any old photographs of Camp Lazear, Camp
Columbia, Columbia Barracks, etc. I would greatly appreciate it if you would be
willing to lend these to me, sending them by registered insured mail at my ex-
pense. I will have them carefully photostated or photographed here and will return
the material intact to you. This would be a wonderful help to me and it is the
only way that I know of that I can get a clear understanding of the important
contribution which your husband made to this work. I note in your letter to Mr.
Kellogg that one of your sons and a daughter are physicians and I am therefore
sending three or four extra reprints, thinking they might like to have them.
Should you wish more, I shall be delighted to send them.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
